ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Value of the class: I gleaned some information from Kris's personal experiences, but this class did not teach the information that was promised in the syllabus. The class needs more structure and depth about how to function in a corporate setting, not just surface level information about how a company is organized.

This class is absolutely useless and does not accurately reflect what is presented in the course description or what was discussed on the first day of class. Things like "what a manager does" or "what HR does" have nothing to do with environmental leadership and the bulk of the course material was presented at a middle-school level. The lecture slides, drawn from some sort of pre-packaged course, are demeaning to our intelligence and only useful for someone that has absolutely no idea what a company or corporation is or does. Everyone sits in class with their laptops open and pokes around on email or facebook and pays little attention to the material being presented, but then again, I can't blame them since nothing presented actually required any thought or attention.That all being said, the instructor couldn't have been kinder, nicer, and seems genuinely interested in helping students navigate the jump between school and the corporate world, and I'm very glad to have met her and to have her as a contact. Now someone just needs to help her develop course material that is actually relevant.
Kris was great and the lectures were engaging. I really enjoyed Shawn's HR lecture. The food served was also fantastic.

This course was a good introduction to the corporate world from an environmental perspective. For a 1-credit professional skills course, the workload was as expected. I did not find it as helpful since it was an overview of corporations (their structure, and issues that typically come up in companies) and I have been in the corporate world for the past five years, and worked with various companies as a consultant. As such, I've seen different companies and how they operate, so it was mostly redundant for me. However, I enjoyed the guest speaker from Honeywell's human resources department, as she had some helpful insight into the application process. I also liked the final project, as we were able to delve into a particular company's environmental initiatives. Kris (the instructor) brings valuable perspectives though, and I'm sure the course is a great overview for people coming from the non-profit world.
I found it was an overall great course. The professor was outstanding

The real-world stories shared by the instructor were quite interesting. Her partner, who works in Human Resources, provided extremely valuable information regarding jobs in this field, the hiring process, and even some tips for salary negotiation. I enjoyed getting to know some new classmates during the group activity at the end of the course.
Dinner each night and hardly any work. If you need one credit and don't want to do any real work, this class is for you.
The real world examples provided by the instructor and guest lecturers.
Friendly professor and TA, casual learning environment, important topic for professional development, and free food! :)
The lecturer provided dinner, which was the best thing about this course.
A nice way to end the day -- offered a broad look at environmental management -- not a lot of technical detail, more thoughtful insight.
The final project allowed us to focus on one company's environmental initiatives.
The chance to hear personal insights and stories from a leader in the corporate world and have candid discussion about our thoughts on the corporate space.
I enjoyed the practitioner's perspective immensely in the mix of my overall classes at school. The guest lecturers were also excellent.
Guest speakers were great.
Instructor is very knowledgeable and helpful!
The teacher was fantastic. She was enthusiastic about what she was teaching and she provided great insight into how the corporate world works in real life.
Practical example based on the instructors experience

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The course could have been structured to be a bit more interactive, although the instructor made sure to provide space for Q&A during each session.

Course material that is actually helpful and teaches me something I didn't know 15 years ago. If you have ever worked - anywhere - don't bother taking this class, as you will already know everything presented.
More specifics on how management applies to environmental careers.
didn't cover enough material, pace was too slow, not challenging, my understanding of the topic was not enhanced through taking the class - too basic, didn't cover leadership

Overall, the content was entirely subjective and the lecturers perspective wasn't all that unique. I regret taking the course.For one of the six lectures, the instructor invited her partner in to speak which I thought was inappropriate.I'd recommend this course be removed.

Environmental Management and Leadership is a bit of an awkward subject to teach...it seems like one of the things you're either naturally good at or not. So, while the class was insightful and interesting, I don't think it could really take someone who's either totally inexperienced with management/leadership and or bad at it and make them a lot better.
Not much substance to this course.
N/A
While I really enjoyed the informal and conversational nature of this course, a focus on more tangible learning outcomes and principles could help strengthen the course.

This isn't a improvement to this course per se in that this suggestion could go a few different routes: As the instructor likes to say, this is a course about environmental management with an EHS overlay (ie, draws on EHS for the stories and examples). I wonder if either another course, or this course, could offer an EHS professional skills class, offering some technical expertise that we might not get in other classes at school (incident report writing, auditing, H&S, etc).
Thought this course was excellent.
More structure, maybe more powerpoint presentations

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Always promptly answered emails. Very kind and thoughtful out of class.
Didn't contact for help.
very available
I'm sure the lecturer and TA would have been available had I sought their help.
N/A
Kris seemed to be very open for discussion or providing advice/assistance, but I did not seek any assistance outside of class.
Great
Instructor was extremely helpful and dedicated

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I wish this course covered some of the actual elements of corporate environmental leadership. Instead it covered things like "what a manager does."
It provides a background in business concepts for those that are unfamiliar, especially students in the business and environment track.
A nice way to round off a degree in masters of environmental management...seems fitting.
I plan to work for a corporation (most likely focused on energy) so this course fit in well with my curriculum.

I wanted to understand the corporate EHS function better (which I do believe this class does, even without the technical skills component I was suggesting in question 13). I am studying industrial ecology and management, along with policy, at the school.
I would like to have a 3 credit class on management.
Gave a great overview of corporate side of environmental management.

This course is much needed at FES. It provided a unique glimpse into the corporate world and what it takes to be a leader in this field. Kris shared stories from her own experience and career path and shared valuable tips for how to make a great career in the business world. Since I am interested in this field this course provided great insights for me.
Leadership is a key skill for any environmental manager, so it was very useful

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: It fit nicely within my course of study.
I thought it would give me insights into leadership within firms and management styles but course was too casual/unstructured to really learn anything
I thought it would be more leadership focused, less about one woman's career story which was again, not that interesting.
Always a good idea to take PSCs
See Question 15.
I wanted to learn more about corporate opportunities.
I took this course to gain a perspective on the corporate world and how environmental leaders can find a place in this field.
Because of content and because I wanted to learn more from instructors experience

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: No, it was too shallow
Not at all. Disappointing.
It was a little more basic than I had hoped.
no
No.
I didn't have too many expectations --- just taking to see what it would be like.
no
I was hoping for more detailed information about corporate structure, practices, trends, etc., but it was a pretty basic overview (for someone that has been in the corporate world for several years).
Not really, I was expecting something more organized.
Yes.
Absolutely. Kris was fantastic and taught us the basics of leadership in the corporate world.
Yes

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: No.
See 17. No.
no
No.
no
See Question 17.
Yes.
Yes.
Very much

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Group work was one meeting the day before it was due with people I never met before and who didn't really do much work. Not exactly a great experience.
group project was fine - got a chance to interact with other students
N/A
The group work was really straightforward and a good experience. The group presentations were a nice way to end class.
I enjoy group work, but we didn't do much, honestly.

The group work at the end of the course was great. It was a light project and just involved some basic research on a company. It was a great chance to work briefly with other classmates and to all share our backgrounds and knowledge about corporations. It was also really fun to dive into a particular company.
I learnt from other peoples experience

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Only take this course if you have ABSOLUTELY no idea how a large company or corporation functions and have no work experience whatsoever.
don't have high expectations
Meet with the professor before and see if she's someone you want to listen to speak for six weeks.
Kris is great -- come to class with lots of questions, because you'll get thoughtful answers from a professional.
N/A

The lecturing and approach might be different from the bulk of our academic classes at school, but I enjoyed hearing the perspective that was offered in the overall mix of my classes. And guest lecturers (though they might rotate) are good, too.
Definitely take this course if you want to learn a little about working in the corporate world. Kris is great, and the weekly dinners are great too!
To enjoy the instructor's enthusiasm for what she teaches
